Award.AwardTitle: Fire ecology research priorities across space and time: support for the Future of Fire workshop; Colorado Chautauqua National Historic Landmark; November, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration: Fires play an important role in shaping and managing ecosystems. The importance of fire in altering ecosystems is gaining renewed scientific attention of ecologists with the increased pace of large, destructive, and seemingly novel fires occurring across a large swath of North America and beyond. Understanding fires occurring in the past decade raise a set of urgent questions for both ecologists and society. Despite the large number of researchers working on fire, there is an ongoing need to unify the approach of researchers working on mechanisms of ecological change and fire. Funding for this workshop to bring together researchers with complementary approaches to reconstructing ecosystems during the Future of Fire workshop. The specific goals of the workshop are: (1) To assess scientific priorities regarding the interactions of fire with ecological processes from population to ecosystem levels, (2) To explore fire science as a central research area within basic science research, and (3) To find areas of synergy among previously separate areas of fire science based within the discipline of ecology but interacting with many other disciplines such as meteorology, climatology, Earth science, geography, and hydrology. The four focal areas are: fire at large spatial scales, fire experiments, modeling fire, and past fire regimes and baselines. The Future of Fire workshop will have several impacts on society and the larger scientific community. Publications and reports from the workshop will be disseminated broadly through scientific society newsletters, publications, and websites. The workshop will engage a diverse intellectual set of participants across career stage, with many initial participants holding the rank of postdoc, assistant professor, or the equivalent. Participants will engage government agencies and NGOs to provide information about the effects of fire on ecosystem processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fire is a powerful ecological and evolutionary force that regulates organismal traits, species interactions, community composition, carbon and nutrient cycling, and ecosystem function. It also presents a rapidly growing societal challenge, due to both increasingly destructive wildfires and fire exclusion in fire-dependent ecosystems. As an ecological process, fire integrates complex feedbacks among biological, social, and geophysical processes, requiring coordination across several fields and scales of study. To achieve this coordination, the Future of Fire workshop was conducted on November 6 and 7, 2017 at the Chautauqua National Historic Landmark near Boulder, Colorado, USA. Forty-five participants from five nations gathered to discuss exciting directions in fire ecology. We explored six critical areas of fire ecology: (1) characteristics of fire regimes, (2) drivers of changing fire regimes, (3) fire effects on aboveground ecology, (4) fire effects on belowground ecology, (5) the role of fuels, and (6) the role of models in fire ecology. 
Training and outreach was also achieved with this grant. This workshop created a diverse network of researchers all focused on fire ecology. An online survey about research priorities in fire ecology was distributed widely to the fire ecology research community. Forty-five participants for the workshop were selected through an open online application process. The participants that contributed directly to the on-site workshop were diverse in terms of career stage, gender, ethnicity, and institution type. Further, participating researchers represented a large amount of scientific talent and several intellectual perspectives. These included a range of spatial and temporal scales, a variety of disciplinary perspectives (but connected with ecology), and representation of fire regimes in most major biomes on Earth.  These researchers are engaged in a variety of active and ongoing new collaborations. Overall, we described the need to study fire across temporal scales, to assess the mechanisms underlying a variety of feedbacks in the fire system, and to improve representation of fire in a range of modeling contexts. As fire regimes and our relationships with fire continue to change, the prioritization of fire ecology research areas will facilitate understanding of the ecological causes and consequences of future fires.
